The purpose of the loan will be to invest in the maintenance and cultivation of 1.5 hectares of cafe in production, ensuring good production for the 2016 season.  This will mean a larger volume of sales and more income that he can use to improve the standard of living for himself and his family.  

Raúl is a recurrent member of Edpyme Alternativa.  He and his partner are signing together.

Thaer is a twenty-four-year-old single man living in Mafraq. He’s studying political science to get his bachelor's degree and is in his third year of study to become a public sector employee. His role model in life is his father, who works in public security. Thaer needs the loan to pay for his semester fees.

Bahtiniso is a capable woman. She is married and has three children. She has been busy with a farming business during some years. She grows a variety of vegetables on land that is rented.

Bahtiniso is looking for a loan to enlarge her business. She is going to use the loan for the land's rent, and to buy fertilizers and seeds.

She believes that by increasing her farming business, she will increase her income. This loan will help her achieve her goals and improve her family's quality of life. She is asking for a loan of 8,000 TJS with this aim. She awaits your help and mercy.

Yaneth, 22, is a member of the Grupo Solidario Superacion Group. She is a single mother with two children, ages 6 and 4, one of whom attends school. She runs a variety store and is requesting a loan to buy Christmas products. Her customers are neighbors, friends and people in her community.

She started out selling juices but was able to earn more profit selling various products. Her goals are to improve her quality of life, increase production and income, strengthen the business, and pay for her children's education.

She has had four loans through FAPE which have helped her to grow her business.

Ana is 43 years old and married. Her husband is a driver who is usually on the road away from home. They have four children who attend state funded school in the area: Alberto, 23, Dario, 19, Wilmer, 17 and Katherine, who is 12. Ana is very cheerful, and has worked for more than twenty years selling cosmetics and clothing, and she also paints figures and makes crafts. She is very creative in the way she tries to support her children so that they do not lack for anything.

Ana is requesting a loan to buy merchandise to stock her business which she runs in the afternoons. She will buy materials for her crafts which she makes at night, and the money she generates from the profit could continue to cover the costs of food and education for her children. Her biggest dream is to own her own home.

Rano is a friendly young woman. She is married and has two children. Her husband helps her with managing the business.

All the money that she earns goes to provide her family with all necessary things, and she is not in a position to save any money for another long-term goal. She wants to use this loan to buy fertilizer and seeds for her corn plants because she wants to develop her agriculture activity. Part of the loan will also go toward paying for labor. This will allow her to make sure all the work is done well.

She wants additional income, and that’s why she needs to improve her business. She is asking for a loan of TJS 10,000 with this aim. This loan will help her achieve her goals and improve her family's quality of life.

Layla is a 35-year-old married woman. She used to work as a secretary for a company, but then thought of starting her own business to earn a better income to help her husband in supporting her three kids.

Layla used the money she saved from her work and opened a beauty salon. Using her connections she was able to furnish the salon with the basic equipment at a good price.

Now that her business is doing well, she is requesting a loan in order to replace the old tools with new ones. She also plans to add a section for manicures to better serve the ladies at her salon.

Mamadou is the gentleman holding the ram by the horn in the group photo. He is a Malian who has never attended school. At age 38, he is married with six children ages 1 to 18, three of them in school. His wife is a homemaker.

Mamadou raises rams. He borrows funds through RMCR to buy rams at local fairs that he later sells in the city. He has been practicing this activity for over 12 years.

Mamadou earns a profit of approximately 10,000 FCFA per head sold which helps him to cover some of his family's needs such as clothing, healthcare and tuition fees. Mamadou is a solvent client of RMCR.

In the long term, Mamadou wishes to be able to borrow larger sums in order to buy more rams and bolster his profits.

Freddy is a member of the Kadahoka Group and lives in Bubanza. He is 25 years old and is married to Aline, a businesswoman.

He has three people he cares for, members of his extended family who are in school.

He has been selling fruit and corn for five years.

He is on his fourth loan with Turame. With the loan he receives from Kiva, he will increase his capital and buy a large supply of corn to resell to make more money.

In the coming years, he would like to have a clothing business.

Julia is 35 years old and lives in her own house with her husband and two children. She has had a store located in her place of residence for more than three years. She has many clients especially her neighbors as she has a variety of products. With the earnings she obtains from her sales, she manages to pay some of the household expenses. She is requesting a loan to buy more soups, eggs, basic grains, soft drinks, candies, pastries, etc to be able to have greater income for a better quality of living.

Carlos, 37, lives in his own house with his wife and two children. He has been working in artisan fishing for over ten years. The experience has given him the opportunity to sell a good quality product so he has a steady stream of customers.

He is requesting a loan to buy the tools he needs to continue his work such as trammels and fishing nets, and to pay for maintenance of the boat seen in the photo, since it is his only source of income.

Shazia is 38 years old, married, and has four children. She lives in Lahore, Pakistan. Her husband operates a general store in which he sells rice, sugar, cooking oil, detergent, soap, biscuits etc. He manages his household necessities from his own store, and sells to relatives as well. He speaks with an even tone, which is impressive, and he easily wins the trust of others. Due to his behavior and tone, he has built up very good relations with his customers. His general store is very famous in the town, and that is the reason his business runs well. 

Due to good relations, Shazia's husband's sales have increased a lot, but he does not have sufficient stock to cope with the demand. Therefore, Shazia requested a loan for her husband from BRAC Pakistan, which he will use to buy more stock of wheat, rice, flour, pulses, soaps, shampoo, detergents, biscuits etc. Shazia hopes that her husband will utilize the loan in a positive way and that this amount will help him to cope with the demands of her family.

Eldeniz is 27 years old, and he is a refugee from the Bilasuvar region. He is married, and he has a son and a daughter. Eldeniz's family is large, and he also supports his elderly parents and younger siblings. He is very hardworking and is a diligent person. He is trying to earn enough income by raising cattle and sheep. In this way, he takes care of his family's needs. He is very energetic and passionate about his job. There are many people in the local market who respect Eldeniz for his dedication, honesty, and business principles. He is a well-known farmer who does a great job in meeting customers' needs.

He has a small shop where he brings natural meat to sell in the market. In the local market, there aren't many people who can provide real, natural meat. That's why people like buying from Eldeniz. Demand is growing in the market because people prefer traditional foods, like kufta and bozbash that consist of mutton and beef, so Eldeniz is planning to expand. Currently, he needs a 1,200 AZN loan to buy three calves. Hopefully, Kiva lenders will support him.

Oscar is 48-years old.  He lives in his own home with his family.  Oscar has made his living in freight transport for many years.  With his earnings, he is able to get ahead.  Oscar wants to make improvements to his home by finishing construction on a room.  However, with that he earns from his work, he doesn't have enough to get it done.  That is why he is requesting a loan.  Oscar will use the loan to purchase the necessary construction materials to expand his home and live more comfortably.

Shazia is 41 and she is married. She lives with her husband and two children in the area of Lahore, Pakistan.

Shazia purchases clothes at cheap rates with the help of her husband and sells them in her locality. She has been doing this for many years, and now she has gotten enough experience and knows the clothing business very well. She wants to utilize her experience and wants to generate more profit, but she needs to take a loan due to her poor financial condition. Due to winter season, the demand for warm clothing has increased as well.

This is the reason Shazia showed interest in taking a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan. She would like to buy a variety of warm clothes to sell. She hopes that she will utilize this loan positively and that she can grow her business. Her dreams are to provide a better living standard and charming clothes for her children.

Vahan is a father of a big family, and with his wife, two daughters and a son lives in Sevan city of the Gegharkunik region. Vahan is farming, and on his farm he has cows, calves, a lamb, sheep and chickens. The sale of his farm products, such as milk, meat, macon (a national dairy product), cheeses and eggs, is the only source of income for his large family and its numerous needs.

Since Vahan is the only bread-winner in the family, all the time he is looking for some other way of earning more money for providing better living conditions for his children. This loan can be very helpful and important for his family and his farm, as well. The loan of 690,000 Armenian drams Vahan requests for the purchase of one more cow for his farm and also fodder for all his farm cattle.

Mrs Hương is 22 years old and married with four children. She has had her retail business selling fish for three years, and is planning to hire more workers in the future.  

Hương lives in Quang Xuong district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province. Her income is lower than the national average, and moreover, this region often suffers natural disasters such as storms because it is near the sea. Hương has no collateral because she can't get a loan from banks or credit institutions. The main hardship she faces is lack of capital.

In 2011, Hương joined Thanh Hoa Microfinance Institution in order to improve her business. Hương has successfully repaid four loans from Thanh Hoa Microfinance Institution so far. Now she is requesting a loan to purchase fish to resell.

Hương is a reputable person in her community, and the leader of her solidarity group. With her profits, Hương hopes for her business to do well, to make enough money to provide for her kids, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

Hồng is 27 years old and she is married with 2 children. She lives in Quang Xuong district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province. Her household was recognized by local government as poor, and moreover her region often suffers from natural disasters such as storms because it is near the sea. She has no collateral because she can't get a loan from other banks or credit institutions.

Hồng has had a retail business selling dry food for 6 years. She is a reputable person in the community and is the leader of her solidarity group. The main hardship that she faces is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan to purchase fish to resell.

In 2011, Hồng joined Thanh Hoa Microfinance Institution to improve her business. She has already successfully repaid 4 loans from them.

With her business profit, Hồng hopes for her business to do well, to build a new house, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business. She is planning to hire more workers in the future.

Murtala is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Murtala has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer. 

Before joining Babban Gona, Murtala would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Murtala can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest. 

As a Babban Gona member, Murtala will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. Murtala is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family, and looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

Salisu is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Salisu is thankful that days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Salisu would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Salisu will store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a date later in the season when he can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize at a premium up to 37% more than the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Salisu now has the opportunity to actualize his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and family members and would like to use this additional income to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

Ibrahim is a maize farmer from Tudu village. As a Babban Gona member, Ibrahim is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Ibrahim would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member Ibrahim can to store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a period later on in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Ibrahim no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Ibrahim hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to.

Maxyne is 27 years old. She is married with 2 children.

She has had a retail shop business for 3 years. She will be using the loan to purchase to buy stock of retail goods e.g. cooking fat, flour and soft drinks to sell to his customers and hopes this will help her to support her husband in paying school fees for their children.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to educate her children well through university.

She is in her second loan cycle and has borrowed KShs 35,000 to be repaid in 12 months

Rilwanu is a maize farmer from Shararriya village. As a member of Babban Gona, Rilwanu is excited about the opportunity to become a better farmer. With Babban Gona’s support, he has the chance to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the average yield in Nigeria.

Before joining Babban Gona, Rilwanu would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Rilwanu can store his maize and sell it in the future for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Rilwanu is grateful to be part of the Babban Gona family and, in the end, hopes to use his increased earnings to provide employment to members of his community through his farm.

Bala is a maize farmer from Agalawa village. As a member of Babban Gona, Bala is excited about the opportunity to become a better farmer. With Babban Gona’s support, he has the chance to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the average yield in Nigeria.

Before joining Babban Gona, Bala would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Bala can store his maize and sell it in the future for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Bala is grateful to be part of the Babban Gona family and, in the end, hopes to use his increased earnings to purchase a motorbike and do business with it.

Abdullahi is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Abdullahi has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Abdullahi would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support Abdullahi can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Abdullahi will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. Abdullahi is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

Alhaji Yunusa is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Alhaji Yunusa is thankful that days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Alhaji Yunusa would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Alhaji Yunusa will store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a date later in the season when he can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize at a premium up to 37% more than the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Alhaji Yunusa now has the opportunity to actualize his dream to grow his agriculture business for himself and family members and would like to use this additional income to provide employment to members of his community through his farm.

Ana Blanca is 24 years old. She is a single mother and has humble origins. She has a three-year-old daughter, whom she gave birth to when she was 21 years old. Unfortunately, the father did not understand his daughter's worth and told Ana to raise the child on her own. This situation encouraged Ana to leave the father, who was preventing her from achieving her dreams and aspirations.

Ana herself was abandoned by her father and raised through a lot of hard work by her mother. Ana finished her education at Achocalla school and went on to study cookery and event management. This knowledge led to Ana opening a business, called "Venta de Platos a la Leña". Ana has premises left to her by her father before his death. She also has ovens, cookers and other tools.

Ana says that she needs a loan in order to organise her premises better to sell dishes such as "pollo a la leña", and "llama a la leña" (chicken and llama dishes). The income that will result from this loan will help Ana to improve her quality of life and prove that she can move forward without the help of her husband.

Gabriel is a 35 years old man from Kisumu, he supports one person and is married.

He has a retail shop, a business he has been doing for the last 10 years and gets a monthly income of Kes 15000.

He has requested for his first loan with VisionFund Kenya which he will use to purchase more shop items.

He will use the anticipated profit to plow back into the business.

His dream is to expand his business.

Kobiljon is a young 32-year-old man full of joie de vivre. He is married and has four children. Kobiljon lives with his family in a small village. All his neighbours get along well with him, since he presents himself as a caring and kind person who is always ready to help anyone in need. 

From his childhood, Kobiljon has helped his father with his business. His father had a restaurant business. Thus Kobiljon also learned about this business from his father. He has been working in this business for five years. He has a small teahouse. He takes orders for events, and he receives a good stable income from this job. Kolbijon has clients at various times of the year. Kobiljon has many clients who are satisfied with his teahouse's service. 

Currently Kobiljon wants to renovate his teahouse, and he needs funds for this. He thanks Arvand in advance for the given support, and hopes for a positive outcome.

Isabel is a hardworking man who has lived with his wife in their own home for the past 25 years. He has worked as an assistant at a recycling company for 11 years, which allows him to provide for his family. Bit by bit, Isabel has improved his home. With a previous loan, he built a barrier wall for his home because during the rainy season water enters the home and damages his belongings.

For this reason, he is requesting a new loan with FUSAI to buy: cement, sand, gravel, and bricks to build a retaining wall in the area shown in the picture, in order to provide better safety for his family.

Yesenia is a hard-working woman who has worked for 1 year taking care of a beachfront property. She is happy for this work as it allows her to support her family. She is 32 years old and lives with her spouse and her 13-year-old son. Yesenia would like to build a room in her house, and so is requesting a loan through FUSAI to buy cement, sand, gravel, bricks and iron to build the room.

Tahira is 43 years old, married woman. She is been involved in the business of the cloth trade. She purchases variety of cloth at low prices from city market and sells them in her own town. She has a strong customer base.

Tahira has requested for a loan of 45000 PKR. She wants to buy greater variety of cloth in different colors for her business to get boost in her earnings with her loan

Rasha is the proud owner of a shop that has been selling all types of home products for twenty years. The shop was initially established by her father in law, but Rasha has successfully run the business for four years.

She is Lebanese, 24 years old, and lives in Beirut with her husband who works in water distribution.
She holds a university degree which helps her manage the shop with the needed skills and knowledge.

In order to develop her business, Rasha is asking for a 1,543,658 Lebanese pounds for the first time from Kiva's partner Ibdaa. She needs to buy new products for her shop before the holidays and the Christmas season.

Rasha is well known in the area and her clients see her as an honest, hard working woman who has a very good reputation.

Robinson is a 20-year-old man with 1 child.

He has had a shoes business for 3 years. He will be using the loan to purchase plastic shoes and hopes this will help him to expand his business and attract more customers.

His hopes and dreams for the future are to get married and build a house for his family.

He is in his second loan cycle and has borrowed 45,000 KSH to be repaid in 12 months.

Nellious is a 22-year-old woman with 1 child.

She has had a shoe business for 3 years. She will use the loan to purchase shoes to expand her business and provide for her child.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to buy a plot of land.

She is in her second loan cycle and has borrowed 40,000 KSH to be repaid in 12 months.

Peris is taking out another Kiva loan to expand her existing business. With the loan, she wants to purchase more stock of clothes for resale.

With her previous loan, she was able to improve her business and her family's living standard as compared to before.

Peris is grateful for the opportunity given by Yehu Microfinance and Kiva lenders to access loans.

Jackline is a 26-year-old single woman blessed with three children. She has operated a profitable retail shop for three years. This is her second loan with VisionFund Kenya and she will buy cooking oil, wheat flour, sugar and detergent to sell. She hopes to make more income and educate her children.

Her future hopes and dreams are to expand her business, make more income, and be successful.

Luka is a maize farmer from Rafin Tabo village. As a Babban Gona member, Luka is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 Metric Tonnes of Maize per Hectare of Land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer. 
Before joining Babban Gona, Luka would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member Luka can to store the maize he harvests and delay it’s sale until a period later on in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.
Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Luka no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2000 per Hectare of land, Luka hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to move into a better home with his family.

Sale is a maize farmer from Madarzai village. As a Babban Gona member, Sale is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 Metric Tonnes of Maize per Hectare of Land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer. 
Before joining Babban Gona, Sale would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member Sale can to store the maize he harvests and delay it’s sale until a period later on in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.
Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Sale no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2000 per Hectare of land, Sale hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to ensure that all his children get a post secondary education.

Ahmad is a Babban Gona maize farmer. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Ahmad is thankful that days of poor yields are long gone. As a Babban Gona member, he has the opportunity to achieve yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times the yield of the average Nigerian farmer.

Traditionally, Ahmad would have had to sell his maize for low prices at harvest to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. With Babban Gona’s support, Ahmad will store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a date later in the season when he can obtain a significantly higher price for his maize at a premium up to 37% more than the harvest price.

With the opportunity to earn up to $2000 per hectare of land, Ahmad now has the opportunity to actualize his dream of growing his agriculture business for himself and family members and would like to use this additional income to ensure that all his children get a postsecondary education.

Aminu is a maize farmer from Dokantoro village. As a Babban Gona member, Aminu is excited to have access to a trained agronomist and superior inputs that will give him the chance to achieve high yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times higher than the average Nigerian farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Aminu would have had to sell his maize at harvest, when the price of maize is at it’s lowest, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. As a Babban Gona member Aminu can to store the maize he harvests and delay its sale until a period later on in the season when he can obtain the best price for his maize at a premium of up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

Thanks to the support from Babban Gona’s marketing services, Aminu no longer feels the pressure to sell his maize at low harvest prices. With the opportunity to earn up to $2,000 per hectare of land, Aminu hopes to realize better yields and plans on using his additional income to provide employment to members of his community through his farm.

Murtala is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Murtala has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Murtala would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Murtala can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Murtala will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. Murtala is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to acquire more land to put into the Babban Gona program.

Idris is a maize farmer and Babban Gona member. Anticipating a good harvest this season, Idris has the opportunity to attain yields of up to 8 metric tonnes of maize per hectare of land, 5.5 times that of the average Nigerian maize farmer.

Before joining Babban Gona, Idris would have had to sell his maize at harvest, a period when maize prices are at their lowest in the market, to meet his immediate cash needs such as food and clothing. Thanks to Babban Gona’s support, Idris can store his maize and sell it at a future date for up to 37% higher than the market price at harvest.

As a Babban Gona member, Idris will benefit from marketing support that could see him generate earnings of up to $2,000 per hectare of land. Idris is thankful that he now has the opportunity to improve the life of his children and family and looks forward to using his additional earnings to ensure that all his children get a post-secondary education.

Miriam is a young woman, 22 years of age, who is very charismatic. She has had to learn to value herself on her own. Her parents migrated outside the country to improve her quality of life. This situation led her to start a business selling in the streets clothing, cosmetics, and articles for the home. Thus, she began to generate income to contribute to her own development. Miriam confesses that it has not been easy but her urge to convert herself into a larger merchant has helped her to not accept defeat.

This season offers growth opportunities for Miriam's business. For that reason, she is applying to Kiva and MiCredito for a loan that will permit her to purchase makeup, clothing for men and women, sandals for girls, and articles for the home, among other products that her customers look for at the time of Christmas celebrations. In the future, Miriam hopes to be able to open a store in her neighborhood, preferably located in some market center in her city.

Norlan, 25, is a young man who loves music and the entertainment world. A few years ago he decided to launch his own business as a DJ for special events. Thanks to support from his father, who lives abroad, he has been buying some consoles, speakers and lights.

Nevertheless, this business has to be continuously updated, which is a challenge for Norlan. That's why he has come to Kiva along with MiCredito to get a loan which will allow him to purchase new equipment, such as an amplifier, speakers with integrated lights and a DJ controller. His next goal is to buy a vehicle which will enable him to get around faster, to offer a higher quality service.

Pedro is 42 years old, is married, and has a daughter. He comments that he has his own workshop where he does his daily carpentry work.

Pedro has already worked for 29 years as a carpenter, which has allowed him to be very well known by many people, since his work is very delicate and is done with good taste. That is to say, he is very committed to his work and goes to more and more effort every day to thus satisfy his customers and have them recommend him to more people.

He needs the loan to buy a cow, since he has a piece of land where he can maintain it to give it the necessary care, and he hopes to sell it in the future at a good price.

Su sueño es continuar trabajando en la carpintería y siempre brindarles apoyo económico a sus hijos para que continúen sus estudios.

His dream is to continue working in carpentry and to always offer economic support to his daughter so that she can continue with their studies.

Angela is 25 years old and lives with her life partner and her 10-year-old son. She has painstakingly managed to advance herself. She is a very admirable woman, who has worked providing housekeeping services for the past 5 years. Angela wishes to construct a hallway in her home and is applying for a loan through FUSAI to buy cement, stones, gravel, bricks, and iron to build the hallway.

Ana, who is 44 years old, lives with her life partner and her two children, who are 11 and 14 years old and are in school. She works selling beauty products by catalog, an activity that she has done for the past 5 years and through which she works with many clients. She wishes to continue improving her home, as she previously obtained a loan with which she improved the fence around her house. She is now applying for a new loan through FUSAI to buy cement, stones, gravel, bricks, and iron to construct a room in her home.

Norbibi very kind and bright woman. Norbibi lives in a city of Tajikistan with her family. She is careful woman of her four children. Her children are adult. She tries to offer the best condition of life.

Norbibi 25 year ago has begun her business for buying and selling shoes because she needed the money. Norbibi buys shoes in a bulk and retails in a local market in low price. That’s why she finds status among other business women. Norbibi time by time renews the assortment of her goods. Norbibi now is going to buy new winter shoes for this winter season. She is asking for 7000 Somoni with this aim. She awaits your support.

Fatuma is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her biggest monthly expense is rent.

For the past three years she has operated a cosmetic selling shop business, selling at retail at the market. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Fatuma dreams of opening a salon business in the future.

With the loan that she is requesting of Kes 40,000, she wants to purchase a stock of cosmetics, including hair chemicals, sprays, lotions, braids and creams to sell.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

Mariana studied to be a chef. She is a 30-year-old entrepreneur with a 4-year-old daughter who depends on her. Over a year ago, Mariana completed training in the preparation of pastas and desserts. Now that she knows this line of work a bit better, she wants to invest in starting up an Italian pasta business, giving it a business focus since she prepared her products in the artisanal way and orders have been placed.

Mariana has good prospects since what most motivates her is to succeed. With various goals to achieve, she wants to get to form a working capital that will give her better economic stability.

Mariana sees that her pasta business can grow and expand to new markets in other localities in the region, and so, have a business focus and achieve the objectives that she herself has outlined throughout her career.

Jane, who is in her mid-40s, is married and has three schooling children.

She has been running a food-vending business famously known as a "mama lishe" for six years. She works from 5 a.m. to 6 p.m. daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be her first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She will use this loan to restore the out-of-stock items in her mama lishe food store.

She dreams of expanding her business into a restaurant.

Jane will share this loan with her loan group, Nyota Kinyamwezi, which has three members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

The members belong to the San Martin de Yanahuara communal bank, which is located in the Urubamba province in the department of Cusco.

Yuri is one of the members and is a hardworking person who wants to get ahead. He works as a waiter in a very important "quinta" [a place where traditional food and drinks are sold] in his neighborhood. Through this hard, taxing work he wants a better future. His dream is to have his own food business to have more opportunities to progress.

Yuri is applying for the loan to purchase shoes and a shirt for his own use since they are a requirement for his job.

The members who are added on in the photograph asked for permission to arrive late to the meeting because of their jobs.

The members are happy and grateful for the loan offered by KIVA investors.

Mrs Anh is 47 years old and she is married with three children. She has worked in agriculture raising poultry for more than 10 years. Anh lives in Hoang Hoa district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province. Her family is a low-income household in the village, and moreover the market need is low in this region. The main hardship that Anh faces is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby poultry and pigs to raise and sell in the future.

In 2010, Anh joined Thanh Hoa microfinance institution to improve her business. She has successfully repaid three loans from Thanh Hoa microfinance institution. She is the group leader of the "Funny Farm" group, which consists of four members. With her business profits, Anh hopes for her children to do well in school, for her business to do well, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

Silpa, aged 29, studied up to eighth grade, is married and has two children with her husband, who are both in school.

Silpa has owned a small shop for five months. She also has a pig farm, and her husband also helps her with agricultural work. She decided to set up a shop in the area where she lives as there is not much competition and a fairly large population.

Silpa needs this loan to buy rice, beans, coffee, sugar, bread and detergent, among other products, to improve her shop's inventory.

Silpa dreams of having a well-established business and providing for her children's needs.

Juana, is 38 years old. She went to school up to the ninth grade. She lives with her 23 year old daughter and her nine year old son who is in elementary school.

Juana sells personal use products such as lotions, deodorants, shampoos, and more. She also sells silver and gold plated jewelry, and that is why she knows her own activity so well. She also grows basic grains.

Juana needs the loan to buy lotions, shampoos, and other personal use products.

Juana dreams of her family having better living conditions and for her children to get and education and have good careers.

Efraín, 41, did not attend school. He is married and lives with his wife and three children, the children attend school and his wife is a homemaker.

He has earned a living in agriculture for many years now, his father taught him this work since he was a child. Efrain owns a plot of land where he works every day, mornings and afternoons. He is applying for this loan to hire help to work with the crops, which are ready to be harvested.

Efrain's dream is to see his children grow up, he's raised them with great love.

Nila continues with her business of selling empanadas (She is seated to the right in the photo, wearing a top with blue and yellow horizontal stripes). She used the loan she obtained to buy cooking supplies to prepare empanadas. She made her payments on time, because she worked constantly and did not experience problems.

Currently the communal bank is continuing to work together. Their revenues have grown. They been able to buy merchandise, raw materials for their work, pay their utilities and fix up their work places.

Nila's business selling empanadas has improved in sales both wholesale and retail as she has been able to complete all her production. She has also had time to take care of her children as her supplies have lasted longer. "I was able to sell wholesale to retailers and this gave me more time to take care of my family", she commented.

Her business is successful as she sells retail and wholesale. The advantage of her business is sales are daily, her disadvantage is the lack of cooking supplies to sell wholesale. Her dream is to have a store selling empanadas. She wants to buy cooking supplies like oil, flour, meat, vegetables and others to sell empanadas wholesale. This is her second loan with the institution in the two years she has worked in this business.

For these reasons Nila is requesting a loan to buy cooking supplies to sell empanadas wholesale.

Patricie is a group leader; aged 44.She is married with 4 children aged between 4 and 13 years. The group is called IKIREZI means “Good people” in English. They sell different products and they wish to expand their business for changing their better future.

She sells cattle and she has been running a business for 2 years. With the loan, she would like to buy more cattle for selling. The profits from the business will be used to renovate her house.

Mrs Thùy is 30 years old and she is married with 4 children.

She has operated a food stallt selling fish for 6 years.
Thùy lives in Hau Loc district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.
Her family is a low-income household in village, moreover the market need is low in this region.
The main hardship that Thùy faces is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan to purchase fish to resell.

In 2012, Thùy joined Thanh Hoa microfinance institution to improve her business. Thùy has successfully repaid 4 loans from Thanh Hoa microfinance institution.
She is the group leader of the "Mama's love" group, which consists of 5 members.
With her business profit, Thùy hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her children to do well in school and for her business to do well.
The child's mother in the photo is a member in this group, she agree to post her child's photo in Kiva's website.

Makich is 32 years old and he lives in Tsovagyugh village in the Gegharkunik region. Makich is not married and he lives with his parents. This young man is a farmer and has been since a very young age. On the farm he has great variety of cattle such as cows, calves, a heifer, bulls, pigs, piglets, sheep, lambs, and chickens. Makich, with the help of his parents, organizes the sale of his great variety of farm products. He sells his farm meat, milk, macun (national dairy-product), cheese, butter, and eggs. Makich also does agricultural work with his father and they cultivate potato, cucumber, tomato, and peppers on their land. This young farmer will be greatly thankful if Kiva lenders help him with loan amount of 690.000 Armenian drams that he plans to use on the purchase of animal fodder for his cattle for the long winter months.

Styopa is 47 years old and he with his wife and two school-aged sons live in Ddmashen village of Gegharkunik region. Styopa used to work as a driver, then he regularly left for an abroad works in Russian Federation but now he is only farming. Styopa has s rather great variety of cattle, so correspondingly a lot work to do in it. As he mentions he used to do all the work with great pleasure and easily, until his health problems started and till today it greatly limits his active work about his farm and makes him feel rather week.

This loan of 1.000.000 Armenian drams Styopa asks since he must pass a medical exam and after also a course of treatment at the hospital for the control of his health state.

Daouda is the one raising his hand in the photo. He is a Malian farmer, 41 years old, married and the father of five children ranging from six to 12 years of age, one of whom attends an islamic school. His spouse takes her of the household and works as a vendor. Daouda is a creditworthy customer of RMCR. He has been raising cattle for six years. He stocks up at the nearby markets and also resells there. Sometimes he forwards his cattle to more distant markets. 

His revenue allows him to provide for family needs (healthcare, education and clothing). He borrows from RMCR in order to finance and develop his cattle business at the right moment to increase his profit. Daouda's challenge is slow sales. He would like to bring his animals to the distant markets himself, which is why he is seeking a larger loan to buy more cattle and increase his revenues.

Maria, 49, lives in her own house with her family. For two years, she has had a small store located at her place of residence. She sells a variety of products such as: soft drinks, staple grains, coffee, soups, eggs, soap, detergents, sugar, etc. With the sales she makes, she is able to cover some of her household expenses.

She is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise at wholesale in order to continue making sales to generate a higher income.

Barakat is 31 years old and from Nablus city. He is married and a father of two children. He started his business ten years ago. Barakat chose to take a loan from ACAD to buy new women's accessories for his cosmetic store to increase his capital, and then sell them to customers in Nablus so he can earn some money and improve his family's standards of living.

Barakat says that the two main challenges to his business are the high competition in the market and the high supply of the imported accessories from China. He is looking to expand his store so that he can sell more items and serve more customers. Finally, Barakat would like to thank ACAD and Kiva for letting him share his story.

Delphine is a group leader; she is 45 years old. She is married with four children, ages 2 to 17 years, and they all attend school.

The group is called ABANYAMURAVA, which means “HARD WORKING” in English. They sell different products and they wish to expand their businesses for them to have a better future.

Delphine sells soft drinks and has been running this business for the past seven years. With the loan, she would like to buy more soda, juice, milk and water to sell.

She plans to have supermarket in the future.

Khadijeh is a married woman and has three children. She is household supplies and novelties household.‎
Her husband is working as a tailor and his income is not enough for cover all the needs.‎
‎ Khadijeh wants to help her husband in the household expenses and she is working hard to provide good education for her ‎kids, therefore she is thinking to expand her business and increase her incomes.‎
She decided to apply for loan and boost her business. She wants to purchase more antiques and new household supplies ‎to sell and improve her standards of living. She is very grateful to Kiva for the support.‎

Eid is married and has five children. After he retired from his work he decided to open his own business which is a grocery store. ‎He started a small project of selling food, supplies, and general products to improve his income. Then he started to ‎make and sell sandwiches to earn even more income.

Eid does not want to stop. He wants to develop and expand ‎his shop, so he has asked for a loan to enable him to expand and promote his shop and buy new products so he can attract more ‎customers. Perhaps this will help him to increase his monthly income and improve his living conditions.‎

Aref is 25 years old and lives in Marka with his wife and his two children. He is the sole breadwinner in his family. Because of ‎that, Aref decided to start his own business to increase his income and improve the standard of living for his family.  Aref ‎opened a grocery store near his home and now he wants to buy more kinds of products and food supplies to sell to attract ‎more customers. Because of that, he applied for a loan to help him buy what he wants and expand his business.‎

Mrs Tám is 34 years old and she is married with 2 children. She has worked in agriculture raising cattle for 6 years.Tám lives in Thieu Hoa district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province. Her family's household is low-income. Moreover, the market demand is low in this region.

Tám is a reputable person in her community. Although this is her first loan with Thanh Hoa Microfinance Institution, all members of her group voted her as the leader of the solidarity group.

The main hardship that Tám faces is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan to purchase calves to raise and sell in the future. With her business profit, Tám hopes for her business to do well, for her children to excel in school, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

Zeynegul successfully repaid her loan, after using for its intended purpose.  She is thankful to Kiva and to all the lenders who have helped her to obtain this previous financing.  She currently has eight cows, 42 sheep, and one horse on her farm.  She also grows potatoes, alfalfa, and barley for resale on 1.6 hectares of her own land and 0.5 hectares of leased land.  She makes a monthly income of 22,000 som (KGS).

Eager to further grow her farming business, she has once more contacted Kiva's partner, Bai Tushum Bank, and she is taking a loan of 150,000 (KGS) som to buy a few additional cows.  She is planning to use the earnings from her loan to further expand her farming business and to educate her children.

Nurbubu is a 48-year-old widow and the mother of four children.  For the past 20 years, she has been involved in agriculture and animal husbandry, two activities which constitute her family's main source of income.  Thanks to her very hard work, she currently has three cows, 31 sheep and two horses on her farm.  She also grows barley and alfalfa on 1.2 hectares of leased land and 1.65 hectares of her own land.  She makes up to 35,000 som (KGS) every month from her combined activities.  Having realized that her farming business could be profitable, she has turned to Kiva's partner, Bai Tushum Bank, and requested a loan of 150,000 som (KGS) to buy six steers for fattening and resale.  She is planning to use the earnings from her loan to further expand her farming business and to improve her family's material well-being.

El Mana communal bank is made up of eight women and a man who are responsible parents with a total of fifteen children to care for. They are from Santa Rosa del Peñon, and can be described as hardworking, responsible people who want to succeed. In their free time they like to enjoy being with their families. They are striving every day to get ahead and give their children the stability that they need.

Thanks to her desire for personal growth, Angela is their coordinator. Her business is making and selling tortillas. Her business is located in her home. She spends twelve hours each day selling her products. Her objective for this loan is to invest in working capital and buy 100 lbs of corn for selling tortillas. El Mana group appreciates the help that Kiva investors offer people with very limited resources.

Mrs. Ly is 27 years old and she is married with one child. Ly lives in Dong Son district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province. Her family is a low-income household in the village.

Ly has had a service business cutting hair for 3 years. In 2014, Ly joined Thanh Hoa microfinance institution to improve her business. Ly has successfully repaid 2 loans from Thanh Hoa microfinance institution. The main hardship that Ly faces is lack of capital, moreover the market need is low in this region. She is requesting a loan to purchase more supplies to maintain her hair salon.

Ly is a reputable person in the community. She is the leader of her "Love kids" solidarity group.

With her business profit, Ly hopes for her business to do well, to make enough money to provide for her kids, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

AROUNA is the gentleman holding the sheep in the photo. He is Malian, educated, 40 years old, a farmer, and the married father of seven children, aged from ___ months to 16 years, of whom two are attending school. His wife is a homemaker.

In addition to farming, AROUNA has been raising sheep for seven years. He is supplied from nearby markets and resells his animals at the same markets. The profit he earns will enable him to meet family needs, such as healthcare, food, etc.

AROUNA is an RMCR client in good standing. Full of initiative, he is borrowing money to increase his buying power in order to increase revenues. He feels comfortable in his trade of his, since he finds it to be quite profitable.

Having often confronted problems with market scarcity, his dream is to become an exporter of animals in the future.

José is 39 years old and is married. He lives with his wife and two children in the municipality of Lempira. He has been growing and selling coffee for ten years. He sells parchment coffee of good quality. His production is sold in the area to middlemen. He is requesting the amount of 20,000 HNL that he will invest in buying fertilizer and paying workers to provide clearing and harvesting of his coffee. His objective is to provide more care to obtain higher production and income. His dream is to plant a larger plantation and doing this be able to improve the quality of living of his family.

Francisca has a sixth grade education. She is married to a carpenter and has three children; two attend school and her daughter works to help her parents.

Francisca has been running a store in her home for two years. She decided to set it up in order to help her husband with the household expenses, as before she only attended to the family. Her children and husband help with the store and household chores in their free time.

Francisca is in need of a loan to buy soap, detergent, oil, rice and other products she needs for the business. This will allow her to add more stock and be able to offer a wider variety of products.

Francisca dreams of expanding her store to help her family enjoy a better quality of life and insure that her children can complete their education.

Nawab is a 34-year-old married lady who has been running a small general store in her community for many years.  She offers a variety of grocery items at a reasonable price and has retained many customers who regularly shop at her store. Nawab makes enough to provide for her family. To fully stock her store, she requested a loan of 50,000 PKR. She will use this to buy rice, sugar, grains, biscuits, oil and flour from the market at lower rates to make her stock available to her customers. In this way, she would be able to consistently meet the increasing demand. Nawab wishes to utilize part of her revenues on providing a good-quality life to her family members.

Stanley learned Paglaum MPC and the financial assistance it extends. As a farmer in Cantabon, Siquijor, he tried his luck and borrowed a loan to jump start his corn production. After several months, he was able to return his borrowed capital. To this day, Stanley feels he owes his good fortune to the Cooperative for having trusted him with the money he used to his business.

Recently, he availed a loan to pay for land preparation like plowing & harrowing and purchase of good variety of seedlings for healthier, heavier and more produce. Stanley wishes to sustain his business and be able to supply corn in the neighboring towns.

Good day, lenders! This is Jamil. Jamil is one of the Ruma agents who live in Bekasi, the satellite city located at the east of Jakarta. He is happily married, and he and his wife have been blessed with two daughters.

As the head of the family, his main source of income comes from working in a local private company. Last year Jamil met a Ruma field staff who introduced him to Ruma. He decided to join Ruma by selling mobile phone airtime credits and serving utility bill payments to his surrounding community. He joined Ruma because he wants to learn how to become an entrepreneur, as well as contribute more to his community.

As the business runs, Jamil hopes to get a working capital loan from Kiva that will be used to process more mobile airtime and bill payment transactions, especially on the weekends. In the near future, Jamil plans to add more products from Ruma to the things he serves, such as e-commerce for low-income communities. Jamil is the one who is seen in the photo. He feels thankful for your kind support.

Good day, lenders! This is Ridwan, one of Ruma's agents. Ridwan lives in South Tangerang, located about an hour's drive from Jakarta, the capital city of Indonesia. He owns a stall where he provides mobile airtime credits to his community. He joined Ruma in 2013 because he wanted to learn how to improve his business, as well as to contribute to his community. He feels happy because the sales executive is kind and helpful to him.

As the business grows, Ridwan hopes to get a working capital loan from Kiva. He will use the capital to provide more mobile airtime credits to his community, especially on weekends. Your loan is important to Ridwan because it will help him improve his business as well as his community, which needs access to such services. As seen in the photo, Ridwan is the one standing in front of his own stall. He is thankful for your support.

Samwel is 27 years old, married to Iyphine and blessed with two children.

He is a motorcycle rider and has been in this business for eight years. He earns a monthly income of Kshs. 18,000.

This being his second loan with VisionFund Kenya, he intends to buy a new motorcycle for transport and hopes this will increase his income.

He anticipates purchasing more goats to raise from the expanded business profits.

His dream is to own a matatu for tax and hiring purposes.

Isaac is 41 years old. He is married to Salome, and they are blessed with 3 children of ages between 13 and 4 years respectively.

He has had a farming business for 20 years, currently earning a monthly income of KES. 40,000. He has borrowed KES. 100,000 from VisionFund Kenya as his fifth loan, after paying the previous loan successful. 

He will use the loan to purchase animal feeds and farm inputs.

His hopes and dreams for the future are to enjoy an improved life with his wife and kids.

The person raising his hand in the photo is David. He is 27 years old and married. He joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in 2013 and has benefited from enterprise development and financial management training.

He does dairy farming. He is borrowing a Kiva loan to repair his cow shed and buy dairy feed. This will enable him to get more milk, and hence get increased income, to cater for his family’s basic needs, such as better food and clothing.

He is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for their support.

Ricardo, aged 27, is married and has a 2 year old daughter. He studied up to ninth grade and works in agriculture, sowing corn, and his wife works in a shop.

Ricardo is an agricultural worker, which helps him earn the income he needs to support his family. A few months ago he decided to start his own business selling shellfish from his motorbike, which has helped him to improve his financial income.

Ricardo needs this loan to buy more shellfish and sell them in the neighbouring communities.

Ricardo's main dream is to build a house and protect his family.

53-year-old Julio went to school until the third grade. He lives with his two children, who are 19 and 17 years old. His children are studying in the "Basic Education" level (this is the equivalent of primary and secondary school in El Salvador). His wife, who works selling fish, has sold fish from the lake for the past 6 years.

Julio knows a great deal about catching and selling fish. He has worked at the trade for the past 8 years and he learned it from his father, who insisted on teaching him the trade so that he could have a steady source of income. With the help of his wife he also works growing grain.

Julio needs the loan to buy fishing nets to better catch fish.

Julio hopes that his children will have greater economic stability and also that his business will allow him to provide for his family.

Josphat is a 33-year-old married man blessed with two children who are 14 and 8 years old.

He has sold charcoal and milk for fifteen years and earns a monthly income of 15,000 KSH.

This is his seventh loan with VisionFund Kenya and he intends to buy more charcoal and milk to resale in the village. He will use the profits to pay school fees for their children.

His dream is to buy a motorbike to transport his milk to the factory.

This is Eunice. Her previous loan was a big help in her business. She was able to buy more supplies for her business. She says her family's living standard has also improved since the last loan. She has been in this business for years now, and it keeps on growing. She works hard to provide income for her family's everyday expenses.

She would like to apply for another loan, this time for KES 50,000 to buy more stock of flour, oil, beans, etc. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs and the educational expenses for her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Mwanakombo is married with two children who attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but no piped water. 

She has operated a food stall business for the past three years, selling at the market to the general public. She faces a major challenge of storage means in her business. She also sells firewood.  Her dream is to buy a fridge to be able to preserve her food in the near future. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase stock of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar, rice and firewood. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

Mwanajuma is a married woman and a mother of four children who attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her goals are to fix an underground water source.

She sells fruits and green vegetables. She always struggles to improve her grocery stall, trying to sell more and save money in order to have a more formal establishment. She also sells water. Mwanajuma is requesting a loan to buy grocery and water for resale.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

Isavary is 26 years old. She is married with one child. She does farming and also has a retail business which she has been running for three years. She will be using the loan to buy cereals such as maize, beans, wheat, and millet to sell and hopes this will enable her to make more profits to provide food for her family and build a bigger cereal shop.

Her hopes and dreams for the future are to expand her business, make more income and be able to improve the living standards of her family.

Erickmar is almost finished with his university degree in Medicine.  He is in his fifth year.  He is very excited because when he finishes his degree, he will be able to serve his country and care for all the people who need it.  In order to finish his studies, Erickmar needs a loan to pay for the last year of university and his degree fees.  After earning his degree, Erickmar will be able to study a specialty and be a professional, which will make his parents feel very proud.

Jay Liza is a sari-sari (varieties) store owner. Sari-sari store is a small retail outlets that can be found in almost all neighborhoods, sometimes even on every street corner, in the Philippines. It is privately owned shop operated inside the store owner’s shop. Jay Liza is a 38-year-old woman has been operated this business for 8 years in the town of Carles, Iloilo. She has been doing this to support her family.

With this, she is asking for a loan to buy more commodities to sell, like drinks, canned goods, noodles, cooking oil, spices, toiletries, candies, chips, biscuits, salt, and sugar. In this way, her store looks full and it will attract more buyers. Jay Liza’s ultimate goal is to expand her business for their sustainability.

Flordeliza is a resident of Baybay, Leyte. She is married and has eight children. Her oldest child is 21 years old, while her youngest child is seven years old. Her husband raised them through their farm; thus, her husband is a farmer while Flordeliza sells imported used clothes known as “ukay-ukay”. She has been doing this for three years to earn and helps her husband in providing the needs of her children.

With this, she is asking for a loan for additional capital to buy imported used clothes to sell. Other part of her loan amount is to buy feed for her pigs and buy “tongog” (a tannin powder used by tuba gatherer to add color to the coconut wine). Definitely, Flordeliza is engaged in hog raising business while her husband gathers coconut wine known as “tuba”. In this way, she will be able to enhance her livelihood and augment her profit.

Honey Lee is always traveling to sell her various consumable products, which gives her an approximate income of PHP 10,000 per month. She needs to help her parents provide for the needs of their family, knowing her youngest sibling is already in college.

Honey Lee is 24 years old and an active member of Paglaum MPC.

Recently, she availed a loan of PHP 15,000 as additional capital so that she can supply the demands of her growing number of customers. The amount will be used to purchase additional stocks for her buy-and-sell business.

Jose is studying for his degree in agricultural engineering, through his profession he wants to grow and thrive in order to be a useful professional for society.

His goal is to receive his degree to be able to work in his career, and one day to be able to continue studying to increase his knowledge.

He is asking for this loan to invest it in his graduation expenses, and thus to be able to cover this expense that he has.

Samini is a married man. he has five children. he describes himself to be honest. he operates a supply business where he sells bread, sugar, flour and other items to other retailers. His business is located in a good area and his primary customers are locals. he describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate working capital. he will use the KES 30,000 loan to buy bread, flour, sugar and other items. This is his second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

Jane is a 35-year-old woman from the town of Carles, Iloilo. She is a single woman, running a sari-sari (variety) store business to support her family. She has been doing this for four years. Aside from this, she also engaged in buying and selling dried fish to the community. With this, Jane is asking a loan to buy grocery items such as chips, candies, biscuits, coffee, powdered chocolate drinks, sugar, salt, canned goods, noodles, spices, eggs and drinks. Other part of her loan is to buy dried fish to sell. In this way, Jane was able to enhance her earnings for her family.

Mildred is married and is the mother of two children. She lives in Nakuru, Kenya. Mildred works together with her husband in the local market where they sell carrots, cabbages, sweet potatoes, paw paw and pumpkins. They have been in this business for over five years, and she dreams of expanding it. With her Kiva loan, Mildred will be able to purchase stock and to increase both her retail and wholesale supplies to satisfy her customers' demand.

Joyce is a 22 year old married lady with 2 children all living in Fort Portal Uganda. She owns a business of general retail selling items like local brew known as waragi, beer, soda, spirits, foods like sugar, rice, cooking oil and many others the business she has been running for two years now. She started on a small scale selling local brews like waragi, Kwete and Mkomboti. She is charged with the responsibility of being a house wife and attending to her retail shop. Hardships like customers who delay to pay her and inadequate capital resources are a major hindrance to her goal of building a permanent house and becoming a wholesaler in her village.

She has asked for a group loan as a member of Mumbagane Tukwatanize Group to help her stock of local brew, beers, sodas, spirits, sugar, rice, soap and cooking oil for selling during this Christmas season. The babies in the photo, are with their mothers who are members in the same group and are still breast feeding, so by the time the photo was taken they were with their parents.

Susan is a repeat client of Ugafode Microfinance. She is a married woman with children.

She is a business woman who operates a retail shop in the city outskirts, selling home product items, especially sugar, rice, soap, cooking oil, beverages, bread and sugar, among other items.

In abid to increase her working capital /expand the business, she has applied for a loan of 1,500,000. She will use the loan to buy stock of plastics, kitchen ware, toiletries, beverages and groceries for sell. She is faced with a challenge of competition and limited capital.

Susan and the group members are very grateful for the support Ugafode Microfinance and Kiva lenders have offered to them since they are now able to fund their businesses.

Mrs Hằng is 45 years old and she is married with 3 children. She has operated a food stall selling fish for 8 years. Hằng lives in Hau Loc district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province. Her family is a low-income household in village, moreover the market need is low in this region.
The main hardship that Hằng faces is lack of capital.

She is requesting a loan to purchase fish to resell.This is Hằng's first loan with Thanh Hoa microfinance institution. She is the group leader of the 09 Hưng bắc, Hưng Lộc, which consists of 4 members.

With her business profit, Hằng hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her children to find a good job and for her business to do well.

Carlos is 43 years old and lives in the municipality of Fredonia. Four years ago, he inherited the family business, raising chickens. His parents started teaching him how to run it when he was a little kid, and now he’s an expert at it. He wants to make his business bigger for the well-being of his family.

He’s asking for a loan so that he can buy more chickens and food for them, in order to have more to offer. He expects that with this loan, he can get more profits, get more clients, be more competitive, and make the business last for a long time. He dreams of buying a house where his family can live happily.

Help Carlos to accomplish his dreams with this loan he´s needing.

Ma. Sisa is a resident in the town of Tolosa. She earns a living running a sari-sari(variety) store and sells merchandise such as noodles, milk, sugar, seasonings, soap, shampoo and assorted canned goods.
Aside from that she also runs a bakery. She sold bread and pastries, as means of supplemental income to its household. She is married woman and has three young children. She would like to filled her store with variety of supplies to cater its demands. She decided to join CEVI to avail loan.

Ma. Sisa has requested a loan to purchase soft drinks and frozen goods. In that way, she will be able to serve her respective clients well. Thus, enabling her daily income to improve.

In the future, Ma.Sisa is aiming to have a healthy family and a sustainable livelihood.

Mohana is a 41-year-old married mother of two. Five years ago, she started working as a hairdresser to help her husband in covering the needs and expenses of their family. She has a good reputation in her region and has her loyal customers.

She is working hard to develop her business, thus today she is acquiring a loan from Kiva's field partner Al Majmoua to buy a car which will facilitate her business and allow her to move to her customers' houses easily.

Mohana hopes to keep on expanding her business to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

Chanda, 20, was an outstanding student when he was in high school. Currently, he is studying at the university to pursue a bachelor's degree business management. He is from Prey Veng Province in Cambodia. His father is a construction worker and his mother grows rice.

Chanda is applying for a 3,200 USD to pay for his tuition fees from the first to the fourth year. When he finishes his bachelor's degree, he plans to have a proper job with a decent salary so that he will be able to save enough money to build his own house and educate his future children.

John is a married man with four children ranging in age from three years to 17 years. He operates a retail business where he sells sugar, bread, flour, cooking fat, and other items.

He has been involved in this business for six years. His business is located in a marketable place and his primary customers are locals. He says that his biggest business challenge is transportation costs.

This is John's first loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. He will use the KES 50,000 loan to buy more milk, soap, bread, cooking fat, and other items to sell.

John will use the anticipated profits to replenish his stock. He hopes that in the future, he will be successful.

Peter is a married man with three children. He describes himself as determined. He operates a retail business where he sells earrings, necklaces, bangles, and other items.

He has been involved in this business for five years. His business is located in a marketable place and his primary customers are locals. He says that his biggest business challenge is inadequate working capital.

This is Peter's second loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. He successfully repaid his previous loan. He will use this KES 60,000 loan to buy more earrings, bangles, and necklaces to sell.

Peter will use the anticipated profits to cater for family needs. He hopes that in the future he will educate his children to university level.

Peter is a married man. He has three children. He describes himself as being focused.

He operates a retail business where he sells stationery and offers photocopy services. He has been involved in this business for five years. His primary customers are students. He describes his biggest business challenge to be price fluctuations.

Peter will use the KES 99,000 loan to buy more stocks of stationery. He hopes that, in the future, he will expand his business.

This is Peter's fourth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. Previous loans were successfully repaid. He will use the anticipated profits to open other business branches.

Naisula is a married woman. She has four children. She operates a retail business where she sells soft drinks, bread, airtime and other items. She has been involved in this business for five years. Her business is located in a good area and her primary customers are locals. She will use the Kes. 50,000 loan to buy more stock of bread, soft drinks, airtime and other items. Her business goal is to have a wholesale business within five years.  She will use the anticipated profits to pay school fees for her children.

With great determination, Pabla decided one day to become independent from her employer and start her own business, so she could receive more income for the service provided. Her previous employer did not pay well.

Pabla is married and together with her husband, they have built a great household. She contributes financially through her chicken and food business.

She is requesting this loan to purchase chickens to raise, ingredients to prepare food, and cooking utensils.

Pabla hopes that this will help her business to continue to grow at the same pace as it has been, so she can continue generating income that will support her household financially.

Maria, without being able to depend on much capital but maintaining the desire to move forwards that people have always noticed about her, finds herself obligated to look for a source of income that will allow her to support her household economically.  

Thanks to a friend who taught her how to run a business, Maria decided to start a business selling clothing and personal-use products from her home, where she has a window to display her goods.   Thanks to the business, she has been able to bring in extra income that allows her to have a better quality of life.  

Because of her excellent customer service and the good quality of her products, Maria has captured the attention of a great number of customers that guarantee her good sales in her business, to such an extent that her lack of capital has become a constant obstacle in her efforts to respond to the large orders that her customers place with her.  

With the intention of buying merchandise for her business, she is seeking a loan to provide her with the possibility of gaining access to more wholesale clothing and personal-use products that she will use to fill her customers' orders. 

Maria hopes that this purchase of merchandise will allow her to continue responding to the demands that her customers make and be able to continue increasing her capital so that her business continues to grow more and more each time.

Julie is 25 years old and lives in the municipality of Puerto Salgar. She has always dreamed of being a successful woman, and she works hard to accomplish that goal. Two years ago she started her own business: she sells different products, like clothes and accessories. The business is something that she started to meet her economic needs.

She’s asking for a loan so she can buy merchandise like jeans, blouses, perfume, and women's bags for resale this Christmas season. She expects that this investment will help her to be more competitive in the market and will help her business to continue in the future. 

She wants to improve the conditions of her house.

You can help Julie to accomplish all her dreams with a loan.

Dagoberto is a veteran with much experience in the country. He is humble, simple, with a great gift with people and enough energy to produce any crop.

He grows plantains and yucca which he works on every day and sells his harvests in the plaza of the municipal market of Valencia.
